awd_titl_txt: EAGER Germination Renewal: Piloting a Center for Transformative Research at Boise State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the critical need to foster transformative research ideas that can effectively address societal needs by developing a Center for Transformative Research at Boise State University. The project builds on a pilot award in which this team demonstrated preliminary proof-of-principle of the ability to build an ASSERTive community - Aligning Stakeholders and Structures to Enable Risk Taking. The proposed Center will have three major components: professional development for research-active faculty and post-doctoral fellows; alignment of university structures to support germination of transformative research questions and ideas; and longitudinal tracking of participants to measure the long-term impact of the Center. Successful development of this Center for Transformative Research could have several important impacts. Not only might it lead to development of new research programs that grapple with societally significant research problems, but it could also serve as a model for other emerging research-active universities.

In piloting a Center for Transformative Research, Boise State University will test a scalable platform for assisting faculty and post-doctoral fellows to pose transformative research questions, and engage students in research. The Center will reside structurally and culturally within the College of Innovation + Design, and will have strong ties to the Division of Research and Economic Development. During the grant period, the PIs will provide focused professional development for participants through retreats and workshops, enhancing their ability to develop their research identity, formulate transformative research questions, and advance their research agenda. A parallel goal is to re-imagine university structures to support the possibility of transformative research among the participants. Necessary conversations will include discussions of promotion and tenure policies, and mechanisms for rewarding high-risk projects and team science. Boise State can be considered representative of emerging research-active US universities - the middle class of higher education. The proposed approach could be scalable and transferable to similar institutions. Boise State's participation in the Vertically Integrated Project (VIP) Consortium, comprised of 24 national and international institutions, offers a potentially tractable route for dissemination.

por.por_cntn:
Inspired by national Centers for Teaching and Learning, and modeled after the emerging Communities of Transformation literature, we piloted a Center for Transformative Research at Boise State University; which has been incorporated into the new Institute for Inclusive and Transformative Scholarship (IFITS). The major goals of our Center were to: (1) provide professional development for research-active and research-emerging faculty; (2) align university structures to support the germination of transformative research questions and ideas among the participants; (3) address the structural, cultural, and personal barriers that prevent faculty from pursuing and achieving transformative scholarship, and (4) begin the longitudinal tracking of participants to measure the long-term impact of the program.

 

In response to these goals, a faculty cohort participated in six types of activities each year including custom-designed retreats, workshops, a faculty learning community, individual mentoring sessions, informal coaching sessions, and a pitch-event to campus and community leadership. The participants were referred to as Faculty Fellows and the fellowship program was called Aligning Stakeholders and Structures to Enable Research Transformation (ASSERT). Throughout the fellowship year, the participants journaled about what they learned and their reactions to the faculty learning community. In addition, grant performance metrics were measured pre- and post-participation in the program.

 

To date, five cohorts with 69 faculty completed the ASSERT program in IFITS. A sixth cohort with 9 faculty is currently being supported for a total of 78 faculty who have been involved in the program. Cohorts four through six have been supported by university funds. Across all cohorts, faculty representation has included the College of Arts and Sciences (n=25), College of Engineering (n=20), College of Education (n=10), College of Health Sciences (n=7), College of Innovation + Design (n=7), School of Public Service (n=5), College of Business & Economics (n=3), and the Albertsons Library (n=1). Also, across all six cohorts, gender identity has been 56% female and 44% male. Professional highlights among the cohorts include multiple NSF CAREER Award recipients (n=7), as well as professional career transitions. Transitions include faculty stepping into Chair or Interim Chair roles (n=4), faculty stepping into Associate Dean or Interim Associate Dean roles (n=4), and faculty stepping into executive leadership roles (n=2). Qualitatively, these transitions are important because they indicate that the ASSERT program is cultivating future leaders at Boise State University. Equally as important, we consistently observed faculty feeling isolated prior to the ASSERT program and then feeling connected to a community of scholars upon their participation. We also routinely observed faculty extending support to each other and developing their identity as scholars; regardless of gender, academic rank, discipline, or age.

 

Quantitatively, cohorts 1 through 6 were awarded a total of 32 grants in the year prior to participating in ASSERT. The cohorts were then awarded a total of 120 grants during and after participating in the program. To compare these values, the number of awards during and after participating in the program were divided by the years of participation. The annualized total was 41 grants. Similarly, during the year prior to participating in ASSERT, cohorts 1 through 6 were awarded a total of $6,735,410 in grants. The cohorts were then awarded a total of $48,624,836 in grants during and after participating in the program. To compare these values, the dollar value of the awards during and after participating in the program were also divided by the years of participation. The annualized total was $14,523,902 in grants.

 

When considering the above, some of which are direct and indirect benefits of participating in the ASSERT program, the resulting outcome is that the Institute for Inclusive and Transformative Scholarship (IFITS) has been institutionalized at Boise State University, as has the Aligning Stakeholders and Structures to Enable Research Transformation (ASSERT) program. What this means is that the size, diversity, and impacts of our faculty learning community will continue to grow.
